  • 02 May 2011 » Interview with Marc Goldchstein - Teacher in Entrepreneurship (VUB/ICAB)
 

Sign up for %>

This study shows a discussion of the theory of advertising in relation with the theory of network effects or externalities. This paper finds that these theories combine into a solid theoretical framework for research on advertising on social network sites and as a basis for empirical research. A good exhibits network externalities if its value depends on the number of adopters. I show that participants of a communication network value the exchange of information more as more people receive that information. Advertisers and their advertisements in social network sites behave in a similar fashion as the exchanged information to produce sales becomes more valuable to them as more people acquire it. In second degree price discrimination, social network sites are able to create producer surplus by adapting their service according to access to the network for advertisers. First, I present social network sites within an adapted version of the traditional network externality models. Second, I explore how this model can be used to study advertising on social network sites. Third, I present social network site Twitter and a few empirical findings from the activities of Fortune 100 companies on this communication network.

Open Source, Test and Running Projects

  • Twilirious: A simple way to push tweets from your mobile phone in one location.
  • Project X: A video streaming test application made in ruby on rails.
  • Splash Art: A self made design piece for use as a splash website.
  • Advertising and Network Effects: A theoretical framework for communication network analysis.

About me

  • In love with entrepreneurship and technology. Intrigued by how you can leverage technology for information collection, diffusion and analysis. Researched advertising and social network sites. Graduated as Master of Business & Technology (Business Engineering) at Solvay Business School.
